Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical and Experimental Research on Voting and Bargaining Games

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is for research on several fundamental open questions about interactive strategic behavior in political economy. The approach combines traditional economic modeling, mathematical tools of game theory, and laboratory experiments to study voting behavior and bargaining behavior. In the last few decades, research by theoretical and experimental economists has made tremendous progress in understanding the basic equilibrium forces that underlie behavior in very complex interactive environments. On the theoretical side, detailed mathematical models have been developed to help understand and explain the diverse and subtle factors that affect voter turnout, political polarization, committee decision making, multilateral bargaining, and related phenomena in the realm of political economy. By augmenting traditional economic analysis with the formal theoretical framework of game theory, many new and important insights have emerged. These insights not only help us understand these very complex phenomena, but also provide guidance for how to improve bargaining protocols, voting methods, and collective decision making institutions. On the experimental side, controlled laboratory environments with human subject participants are created as realistic parallels of the situations being modeled theoretically. This allows sharp tests of the hypotheses generated by the theory, and at the same time provides detailed micro-data to enable the measurement of key driving behavioral variables such as risk aversion and social preferences. This in turn feeds back to the theoretical modeling in order to fine-tune the theories to more closely match observed behavior.

The specific research to be undertaken encompasses three research areas: (1) The Dynamic Political Economy of Public Goods; (2) Vote Trading; and (3) Income Taxation, Redistribution, and Economic Efficiency. The research in the first area is based on repeated bargaining models under the shadow of a voting rule. Outcomes of the bargaining process evolve over time, with current outcomes affecting opportunities for future bargaining agreements. We study the dynamics of public investment and the effects of voting rules and political institutions on economic efficiency. The second area of study investigates different voting mechanisms that produce outcomes sensitive to preference intensity. Specifically for this study, we are investigating the theoretical and behavioral properties of vote trading and logrolling across issues. We aim to characterize stable vote allocations, focusing on existence, efficiency, and comparison to the majority preference relation. The third part of the project develops equilibrium models to compare the effects of different political institutions on income taxation, redistribution and economic efficiency. The hypotheses generated from these theoretical models are then investigated experimentally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted under the project developed new theoretical models to better understand important questions in the general area of political economy, and carried out a series of laboratory experiments that allowed a close examination of the predictions of these theories in highly controlled setting. The theoretical and experimental findings were published in the leading academic journals of economics and political science. Most of the published studies fall under three general categories: (1) the political bargaining dynamics of investment in public projects; (2) the economic and political forces affecting demand for income taxation and redistribution; and (3) the consequences of logrolling and strategic vote trading in committees and legislatures.

Concerning (1) a central role of government is the provision of public goods to its citizenry. Most public goods provided by governments are durable, and hence dynamic in nature. It takes time to accumulate them, and they depreciate slowly, projecting benefits for many years. Prominent examples are national defense, environmental protection, and public infrastructure. Two political economy questions immediately come to mind. First, what affects the efficiency of dynamic public investment by legislatures or governing bodies operating under democratic rules? Second, to what extent does the efficiency depend on the voting rules and procedures under which these governing bodies operate? The general finding of the project?s research in (1) is that agenda power in political bargaining generally leads to inefficiently low public investment, which can be partially mitigated by at least factors: long-term commitment to and irreversibility of investments; and the use of supermajority rules in policy-making bodies.

The goal of the research in category (2) is a deeper understanding of the interaction between economic and political institutions on income taxation, redistribution, and economic efficiency. There is a fundamental tradeoff between the level of redistributive income taxes (and hence the level of public expenditures) and the efficient functioning of the economy, that is captured here by income tax distortions to labor supply. Inequality arises from heterogeneity of individual productivities, which leads to different indirect preferences over tax rates. Political institutions are the means by which these heterogeneous preferences are aggregated into a public decision on the tax rate. However, because the tax rate in turn will affect the amount of income that is generated by the private economy, the preferences themselves are endogenous and depend on how taxes affect individual labor supply decisions, and in this way political and economic decisions are mutually dependent on each other. One general finding from the research in (2) is that democratic politics will lead to income tax rates that significantly redistribute income, but not nearly to the extent that lowering tax rates would lead to a supply-side increase in tax revenue. Furthermore, increased income mobility in the population will generally lead the political process to lower taxes, less tax-induced income redistribution, and more efficient outcomes.

The motivation behind the studies in category (3) is the widespread observation that logrolling and vote trading play an important role in the political bargaining process of policy-making committees and legislatures. Yet little is understood about the consequences of these informal processes for public policy. The research conducted under this project found that logrolling and strategic vote-trading in committees can lead to stable outcomes in a very general sense, but at the same time lead to outcomes different from a majority would prefer if logrolling and vote trading were restricted.

The project conducted several other studies to investigate: the effect on election on turnout of pre-election intercommunication between voters; the polarization effect of costly entry into political campaigns; and the design of voting procedures to lead to more informative and efficient group decisions. All of the studies combined theoretical modeling with the design and implementation of controlled laboratory experiments in which human subjects were provided monetary incentives to approximate the environments developed in the theoretical models.

In terms of its broader impact, the project outcomes included the development and testing of public domain software for running laboratory experiment, and the training of PhD students in the laboratory and theoretical methods of economics and political science, including several who became coauthors on the projects described above.
